issue.title: Axes tab - control over loop order of parameter space and shuffling of individual axes

content.raw:
I would suggest that rather than displaying the hierarchy as a True tree, you "fake" the same format of tree by adding white-space indentation to the first column. 

This has the following benefits:

* Reordering the list becomes easier. We already have code to do most of this (see downsides list below). 
* You can use the child rows of an entry to display the global names that are part of the zip group

This has the following downsides:

* When re-ordering, you have to strip the whitespace from the first column and re-add it correctly for the two items which have swapped. This adds some complexity to the sorting algorithms we already employ.
 
I think that the first upside and downside probably cancel each other out in terms of coding complexity. So the net benefit is probably only a nicer way of displaying the names of globals in zip groups!
content.html:
I would suggest that rather than displaying the hierarchy as a True tree, you "fake" the same format of tree by adding white-space indentation to the first column.

This has the following benefits:

  • Reordering the list becomes easier. We already have code to do most of this (see downsides list below).
  • You can use the child rows of an entry to display the global names that are part of the zip group

This has the following downsides:

  • When re-ordering, you have to strip the whitespace from the first column and re-add it correctly for the two items which have swapped. This adds some complexity to the sorting algorithms we already employ.

I think that the first upside and downside probably cancel each other out in terms of coding complexity. So the net benefit is probably only a nicer way of displaying the names of globals in zip groups!

issue.title: Axes tab - control over loop order of parameter space and shuffling of individual axes

content.raw:
Having these controls would be really nice! 

What is the order in which expansions get applied currently? Is there any way of influencing it?
content.html:
Having these controls would be really nice!

What is the order in which expansions get applied currently? Is there any way of influencing it?

issue.title: Axes tab - control over loop order of parameter space and shuffling of individual axes

content.raw:
Presently I can see that the axes of expansion go through a dictionary at one point, keyed by name, and then the order of the outer product is the order that they come out of the dictionary when iterated over, which is arbitrary. In Python 3.6 (I tihnk?) the dict implementation changed such that insertion order is preserved (though it's an implementation detail not guaranteed by the spec of the language itself), but in python 2, it's going to be something like how the strings for the names of the globals hash. Only way to influence them without changing runmanager code would be to append random gibberish to the globals until you got the order you wanted :p.

Better way of doing it is to finish this feature - which I haven't forgotten about even though it's been  years! I agree with phil's comments, and this is one of the things on my list - it won't be super hard once I get to it.
content.html:
Presently I can see that the axes of expansion go through a dictionary at one point, keyed by name, and then the order of the outer product is the order that they come out of the dictionary when iterated over, which is arbitrary. In Python 3.6 (I tihnk?) the dict implementation changed such that insertion order is preserved (though it's an implementation detail not guaranteed by the spec of the language itself), but in python 2, it's going to be something like how the strings for the names of the globals hash. Only way to influence them without changing runmanager code would be to append random gibberish to the globals until you got the order you wanted :p.

Better way of doing it is to finish this feature - which I haven't forgotten about even though it's been years! I agree with phil's comments, and this is one of the things on my list - it won't be super hard once I get to it.

issue.title: Axes tab - control over loop order of parameter space and shuffling of individual axes

content.raw:
Implemented the axes tab. Fixes issue #31

* Globals (and zip groups) that are being expanded upon to make maultiple shots are now displayed in the axes tab.
* You can reorder the globals/zip groups which will now change the order in which they are expanded over.
* Expansion occurs over globals as if the hierarchy represented nested for loops in Python (so you iterate over all values in the most indented (lowest) level first for a fixed value in each higher level, etc.)
* You can now shuffle specific globals only.
* The global shuffle is now a tri-state checkbox and will toggle shuffle on/off for all globals/zip groups
* The global shuffle also shuffles the set of shots (as before) if all globals/zip groups are set to shuffle (which ensures that you don't get any grouping by the higher levels as you would only be shuffling the order of values within a single global/zip group)
* The axes tab is saved in the runmanager configuration file (it doesn't make sense to save it in the globals file as the axes tab may show the expansions that span multiple h5 files if you are drawing globals from multiple files)

→ <<cset 56a7da0a468c>>
content.html:
Implemented the axes tab. Fixes issue #31

  • Globals (and zip groups) that are being expanded upon to make maultiple shots are now displayed in the axes tab.
  • You can reorder the globals/zip groups which will now change the order in which they are expanded over.
  • Expansion occurs over globals as if the hierarchy represented nested for loops in Python (so you iterate over all values in the most indented (lowest) level first for a fixed value in each higher level, etc.)
  • You can now shuffle specific globals only.
  • The global shuffle is now a tri-state checkbox and will toggle shuffle on/off for all globals/zip groups
  • The global shuffle also shuffles the set of shots (as before) if all globals/zip groups are set to shuffle (which ensures that you don't get any grouping by the higher levels as you would only be shuffling the order of values within a single global/zip group)
  • The axes tab is saved in the runmanager configuration file (it doesn't make sense to save it in the globals file as the axes tab may show the expansions that span multiple h5 files if you are drawing globals from multiple files)

→ <<cset 56a7da0a468c>>
